bibl.title: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, April 3, 1922

div1.p: Parker informs Carter that he is not permitted to continue malaria work in Cherokee County, Mississippi, but that the county health department will continue the work. He is now beginning the Yazoo County campaign and planning a mobile laboratory.

div1.head: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, April 3, 1922
div1.opener:
Malaria
Parker
Yazoo City, Miss.,
April 3, 1922.
Dear doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
I received your letter of
March 21st., and greatly appreciate your
comments on the report of Cherokee County.
I had planned an intensive county - wide
malaria control program - a 5 to 10 year
plan, and feel a keen disappointment in
not having been allowed to carry it through.
I understand, however, from newspaper articles,
that the work I did is being used as a
foundation to establish a County Health
Department with malaria control as a
base of operations. The adjoining county,
Nacogdoches, had expressed a desire to
follow the lead of Cherokee County in
malaria control.

The item of transportation in
my report is rather misleading, I am
sorry to say, as the expense listed under
that head embraces only incidental expenditures.
My private car was used for which no
charge was made against the county, and a
salary of $228.00 per month paid to a local
doctor included the use of his car.

At present I am starting a campaign
in Yazoo County and hope to meet with
success from all angles. Other than the
general control and educational features,
it is planned to operate a mobile laboratory,
not to take a blood index of the county but
primarily for demonstration purposes.

I deeply appreciate your letter - and
with best wishes remain-
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, George Parker. Dr. H. R. Carter,
Asst. Surgeon General, U. S. P. H. S.,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
